Key Match Events: Cleveland led the last 9:05 of the game, although it was almost entirely within five points.
The Thunder went into the game having won nine straight games.
Cleveland won the game 129-122 despite the high score.
Pre-Game Insights: The Thunder (30-6, currently No. 1 in the Western Conference) got the showcase in the biggest regular-season game thus far that counted toward its record.
Cleveland (32-4, currently No. 1 in the Eastern Conference) have now won 11 straight after pulling out the 129-22 victory against OKC at home.
Chet Holmgren is still out for a while due to a hip injury.
Jaylin Williams, the 6-8 forward, has only played nine games after missing the first part of the season due to illness.
Kenrich Williams, a 6-7 forward, has seen his action scaled down.
Post-Match Reflections: Shai Gilgeous-Alexander scored a game-high 31 points on Wednesday, but didn't get all his ideal 3-point looks while going 1-of-6 from long range.
The Thunder don't have many forward-sized players.
Even though OKC and Cleveland are small markets, many want to see more of this (perhaps in the NBA Finals).
David Aldridge of The Athletic requested a seven-game series between them.
Old-time Boston Globe writer Bob Ryan declared Thunder-Cavs to be 'basketball as it should be.'
If the Thunder get to their first NBA Finals since 2012 and face the Cavs, they will have time to make sure Holmgren is healthy and set their defense against an elite offensive team.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Thunder struggled in rebounding, especially in the fourth quarter.
Cleveland outrebounded OKC 40-38, including 10-6 in the fourth quarter.

The Thunder shot 53.3 percent from the field while the Cavs shot 52.2 percent, but the Cavs made 41.7 percent from 3-point range on 36 attempts against 35.5 percent on 33 attempts by the Thunder and hit 20 of 27 free throws while the Thunder only got 17 free-throw attempts and made 15.
